 We remain a key supplier in U.S. 3-tier brick-and-mortar distribution . In addition, we are advancing our aim to become a global, omni-channel competitor in line with consumer preferences . We continue our efforts to progressively expand into DTC channels (including hospitality) and 3 tier eCommerce, and international markets .

We are the #1 brewer and seller of imported beer in the U.S. market. We have the exclusive right to import, market, and sell our Mexican beer brands .
 During Fiscal 2025, we spent nearly $940 million on planned expansions and execution of optimization initiatives and ongoing construction of the Veracruz Brewery . We expect to spend approximately $2 billion over Fiscal 2026 through Fiscal 2028 largely on such activities . We believe these investments allow us the opportunity to further expand our leadership position in the high-end segment of the beer market .
 We are a higher-end wine and spirits company in the U.S. market, with a portfolio that we believe will generate higher growth and higher margins . In Fiscal 2026, we launched Corona Sunbrew nationwide, a beer brewed with real citrus peels and a splash of real citrus juice, also launched in select markets .
 In April 2025, we entered into a definitive agreement to fully divest and, in certain instances, exclusively license the trademarks of a portion of our wine and spirits business . We continue to believe that beyond Fiscal 2026 our Wine and Spirits business will return to net sales growth supported by our continued efforts to better align our portfolio with our focus on broader consumer-led premiumization trends .
 When we advertise our products to consumers, we use a combination of methods to forecast the number of advertising impressions made on individuals at or above the legal drinking age . We are a corporate member of Responsibility.org, a national not-for-profit that aims to empower adults to make a lifetime of responsible alcohol choices . Our Global Code of Responsible Practices for Beverage Alcohol Advertising and Marketing provides the framework for responsible brand advertising and marketing .

In states where the government acts as the distributor, we distribute our products through state alcohol beverage control agencies . We also have various licenses and distribution agreements for the sale, or the production and sale, of our products and products of others .
 As of February 28, 2025, our production capacity at our Mexican breweries was approximately 48 million hectoliters . By the end of Fiscal 2028, we expect to increase our capacity in Mexico to approximately 55 million hectolines . In the U.S., we currently operate 12 wineries using many varieties of grapes grown principally in the Napa, Sonoma, Monterey, and San Joaquin regions of California as well as the Willamette Valley region of Oregon .
 The principal components in the production of our Mexican beer brands include water; agricultural products, such as yeast and grains; and packaging materials, which include glass, aluminum, and cardboard . The current Mexican breweries each receive water originating from separate and distinct aquifers . We aim to reduce operational waste and enhance our use of returnable, recyclable, or renewable packaging .
 Most of our annual grape requirements are satisfied by each year’s harvest . As of February 28, 2025, we owned or leased approximately 18,000 acres of land and vineyards in the U.S., New Zealand, and Italy . Following the anticipated completion of the 2025 Wine Divestitures Transaction, we expect to own or lease approximately 11,400 acres .
 Glass bottles are the largest component of our cost of product sold, comprising more than 95% of our package format mix of our wine and spirits portfolio volume sold for Fiscal 2025 . We have traditionally obtained, and continue to obtain, our glass requirements from a limited number of producers under long-term supply arrangements . We are subject to a range of laws and regulations in the countries in which we operate .
 The beverage alcohol industry is subject to seasonality in each major category . We believe we are in compliance in all material respects with all applicable governmental laws and regulations in the countries in which we operate . We also believe that the cost of administration and compliance with, and liability, does not have, and is not expected to have, a material adverse impact on our financial condition, results of operations, and/or cash flows .
 As of February 28, 2025, we had approximately 10,600 employees . The number of employees will change throughout the year, such as when we have additional workers during the grape harvest season . We consider our employee relations generally to be good. We focus on: (i) serving as good stewards of our communities, (ii) promoting responsible beverage consumption .
 Constellation Brands, Inc. provides pay, benefits, and services that meet the needs of our employees . The main components of compensation are: (i) base pay, (ii) long-term incentives dependent on a number of factors such as geographic location, market prevalence, and level which can include restricted stock units, stock options, and performance share units .
 The Board of Directors is looking at the future of the world's largest economy . It is looking to develop a new generation of people who want to be involved in the process of developing their own businesses . The board is also looking at ways to improve the quality of life in the world of business development and business development . The Board plans to work together with the public to improve their own lives .
 Work-related injuries resulting from the production of our beer, wine, and spirits products are well below industry average . We empower our employees to engage in the communities where they live and work in a variety of ways . We match donations ranging from a maximum of $5,000 to $50,000 per year, depending on employee level, to charitable organizations .
 William A. Newlands has served as Chief Executive Officer of the Company and as a director since March 2019 and as President since February 2018 . James O. Bourdeau has been Executive Vice President and Chief Legal Officer . Mr. Newlands joined the Company in January 2015 . He served from October 2011 until August 2014 as Senior Vice President, President, North America of Beam Inc. Beam Inc., a producer and seller of branded distilled spirits products, merged with a subsidiary of Suntory Holding Limited, a Japanese company .
 Mr. Bourdeau is the Executive Vice President and Chief Legal Officer of the Company, having served in the role since December 2017 . Ms. Erickson served as Senior Vice President, Chief People, Culture, and Communications Officer with Beam Suntory Inc. from January 2023 until April 2024 . She worked for Ace Hardware Corporation in various leadership positions across advertising, brand development, communications, and public relations .
 Before joining the Company, Mr. Glaetzer served in roles of increasing responsibility with Treasury Wine Estates and its predecessors from 1996 until 2014 . He joined Constellation in September 2014 as Senior Director, Communications – Beer Division . Michael McGrew is Executive Vice President, Chief Communications, CSR, and Inclusion Officer of the Company .
 Mallika Monteiro is the Executive Vice President, Managing Director, Beer Brands and Interim Chief Growth and Strategy Officer of the Company . She joined Constellation in October 2016 as vice President, Beer Innovation and was given additional responsibilities as Chief of Staff to the Company’s Executive Management Committee in July 2018 . Before joining the Company, she was a Senior Marketing Director at Anheuser Busch InBev.
 Constellation Brands, Inc. CEO James Sabia is Executive Vice President and President, Beer Division, having served in the roles since January 2022 and February 2022 . Before joining the Company, Mr. Sabia was with Molson Coors Brewing Company for 17 years .
